title: Annual trends in reported landings
summary: Fisheries catches can be expressed by species, functional groups, gear type, and country. Catches and landings are often used as synonyms, though the difference (discards) is important to evaluate stress on the ecosystems.  ‘Landings’ do not include discards at sea.  Moreover, some of the landed catch may remain unrecorded (especially when caught illegally).  Thus the precise term for this component is ‘reported landings’
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Stress (level 1)
definition: Fisheries catches can be expressed by species, functional groups, gear type, and country. Catches and landings are often used as synonyms, though the difference (discards) is important to evaluate stress on the ecosystems. ‘Landings’ do not include discards at sea. Moreover, some of the landed catch may remain unrecorded (especially when caught illegally). Thus the precise term for this component is ‘reported landings’
unit: Weight in tonnes.year-1
rationale: Fisheries have very strong impact on marine ecosystems. Overexploitation/ depletion of fish stocks are among the priority transboundary issues identified in LMEs. One of the foci of GEF LME projects is to recover depleted fisheries.
interlink: There are strong linkages between especially coastal, shelf, and open ocean systems, notably associated with migration and ontogenetic shift in distribution.
measurements: Catches in the Sea Around Us database are based on catches reported to FAO combined with national or regional databases. In addition, catches from parts of the fishing sector that is not or only poorly covered in the official statistics is added through ‘catch reconstruction’ (Zeller and Pauly 2007). The Sea Around Us allocation process use the taxonomic identity of the catch (after the disaggregation process) to allocate catch to the system of spatial cells based on taxonomic distributions (Close and others 2004). Also used is information about fishing access and fishing patterns of reporting countries (where possible after the effects of reflagging are removed) (Watson and others 2004). Maps of catches by all gear types annually since 1950 are also available. The catch data is associated with likely associated fishing gear types based on reported associations by fishing year, fishing country and landed taxa (Watson and others 2006a, 2006b). Application to LMEs is described by Pauly and others (2008).
scale: Catches reported by FAO are by reporting country and statistical areas. Catches from Sea Around Us project are allocated to spatial cells and with finer spatial (½° by ½°) and taxonomic resolution and breakdown to gears.
data_source: Sea Around Us annual catches by LMEs are available from 1950 -2006 at www.seaaroundus.org. Fisheries indicators require accurate and complete catch data, which are not available for most countries. The methods used for re-expressing FAO’s global reported landings dataset on a spatial basis cannot compensate for these limitations. Rather, it makes them visible, and emphasizes the need for catch reconstruction at the national level (sensu Zeller and others 2006, 2007). IUU catches may account for up to 30% of the catches globally, and better estimation of this is warranted. Using flag of convenience may obscure where benefits from fishing are accrued.

title: Catch from bottom impacting gear
summary: In order to provide an indicator for the purposes of classification at the LME-scale, the proportions of catch from bottom trawling gears was calculated for each LME (i.e., collapsing over the fishing country). A 10-year average of the proportions was used in order to provide a single indicator value per LME.
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 1)
definition: In order to provide an indicator for the purposes of classification at the LME-scale, the proportions of catch from bottom trawling gears was calculated for each LME (i.e., collapsing over the fishing country). A 10-year average of the proportions was used in order to provide a single indicator value per LME.
unit: Percentage
rationale: Evaluate the level of risk of each LME’s ecosystem using the level of destruction to the bottom habitat as an indicator.
measurements: Annual landings by bottom-impacting gear types, including dredges and bottom trawls, were extracted from the Sea Around Us database from 1950 to 2006. As the Sea Around Us extended catch data from 2007 to 2010 are not aggregated by gear type, we estimated the catch of bottom-impacting gear types (i.e., trawling and dredging gears) by calculating the proportions of these gear types to the total catch by each fishing country and LME combination in 2006. We then used these proportions to estimate the catch by bottom-impacting gear types from 2007 to 2010. The undeveloped and the developing categories will by definition have disappeared by the end of the time series since the scale is based on the year with maximum catch (which has to occur somewhere on the time line),
scale: Analysis can be done at the national, LME, Regional Seas level, i.e. at any level where it is deemed appropriate to relate stock status to the signals from landings.
data_source: Sea Around Us catch database, FAO
agencies: University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre, Vancouver, Canada - Sea Around Us

title: Chlorophyll-A
summary: Primary productivity is the rate of organic matter production by plants (photosynthesis). The bulk of marine primary productivity is carried out by phytoplankton, which can be seen from space due to their photosynthetic pigments (mainly chlorophyll).
module: Productivity
definition: Primary productivity is the rate of organic matter production by plants (photosynthesis). The bulk of marine primary productivity is carried out by phytoplankton, which can be seen from space due to their photosynthetic pigments (mainly chlorophyll).
unit: mg.m-3
rationale: Measurement of chlorophyll can be a useful indicator of the growing problem of coastal eutrophication.
interlink: Rivers are a central link in nutrient transfer from watersheds to coastal systems, and resulting eutrophication and water quality degradation in LMEs.
measurements: Primary productivity estimates originate from ocean color sensors and satellites including the Ocean Color and Thermal Sensor (OCTS), Sea-viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor (SeaWiFS), and Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS-Aqua and MODIS-Terra). A large archive of in situ near surface chlorophyll data, and satellite SST measurements made by Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) flown on NOAA satellites is used to quantify spatial and seasonal variability of near-surface chlorophyll and SST. Plankton can also be measured over decadal time scales by continuous plankton recorder systems as deployed by the Sir Alistair Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS) from commercial vessels of opportunity.
scale: Globally for all LMEs, Annual trends 1996-2013
data_source: NOAA’s Northeast Fisheries Science Center, Narragansett Laboratory.
agencies:
NOAA’s Northeast Fisheries Science Center, Narragansett Laboratory; University of Rhode Island.

title: Completeness indicator
summary: The completeness indicator is the degree to which there is institutional provision for each of seven stages of the policy cycle for all of the  arrangements that is in place to address one or more transboundary issues of concern within each LME. The seven stages of the policy cycle are: analysis and advice (policy and planning), decision-making (policy and planning), implementation, review and data and information.
module: Governance
definition: The completeness indicator is the degree to which there is institutional provision for each of seven stages of the policy cycle for all of the arrangements that is in place to address one or more transboundary issues of concern within each LME. The seven stages of the policy cycle are: analysis and advice (policy and planning), decision-making (policy and planning), implementation, review and data and information.
unit: Percent
rationale: The provision of each of these policy cycle stages within all arrangement is considered to be an important component of the institutional arrangements needed for governing transboundary issues of concern in LMEs. The current literature on governance architecture suggests that effort should be made to increase the level of completeness of the policy cycle for all arrangements. This is seen as critical as it strengthens and facilitates the flow of data and information into the analysis and advice stage of the cycle which in turn provides the structures that contributes to informed decision-making, implementation and review.
interlink: Processes in place that influence decisions taken within transboundary rivers systems and lakes have the potential to significantly affect governance of transboundary issues in LMEs and subsequently, the open ocean. This is most noticeable for land-based sources of pollution which find their way to LMEs and eventually the open ocean. Arrangements in place to address biodiversity as well as fisheries for species that are diadromous can also be impacted by governance processes in place (or not) within other transboundary water systems.
measurements: Completeness is based on a four-point scale for each of seven stages of the policy cycle. The scores in each case may range from 0 to 3 and are intended to reflect the institutional strength of the arrangement for transboundary governance at that particular policy cycle stage. An overall policy cycle completeness score is derived from the sum of scores of the individual stages and expressed as a percentage. The completeness for the LME is the average completeness for all arrangements in that LME.
scale: Regionally for all LMEs
data_source: Proximate: TWAP LME and Open Ocean arrangements database. Ecological footprint by fisheries in LMEs

title: Ecological footprint by fisheries in LMEs
summary: Ecological footprint is estimated based on the trophic level of the catches, and it is often calculated as a fraction of the total primary production. This corresponds directly to the ecological footprint of the fisheries.
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 1)
definition: Ecological footprint is estimated based on the trophic level of the catches, and it is often calculated as a fraction of the total primary production. This corresponds directly to the ecological footprint of the fisheries.
unit: NA
rationale: The footprint of fisheries is an indicator of sustainability and provides an index for assessing the impact of the fishing.
measurements: See Sea Around Us (www.seaaroundus.org) and Pauly and others (2008) for details. Calculation of the PPR to produce a given tonnage of fish is based on the average trophic level of the fish in question, an assumption about trophic efficiency (10%) and the equation PPR = landings×10(TL-1) (Pauly and Christensen 1995). PPR is calculated separately for each species (or group of species) for the fleets of all countries operating in the area, expressed in terms of the primary production PP). The relative PPR expresses PPR as percentage of PP (based on SeaWiFS data). PPR can also be calculated (more accurately) based on food web information rather than the indirect, but more accessible trophic level-based approach (Christensen and Pauly 1993).
scale: Can be estimated at ½° latitude by ½° longitude, and by LME. Covers 1950 – 2006
data_source: Data available based on catches from Sea Around Us project and trophic levels from FishBase and SeaLifeBase.
agencies: University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre, Vancouver, Canada - Sea Around Us
references:
Christensen, V., and D. Pauly. 1993. Flow characteristics of aquatic ecosystems, p. 338-352. In V. Christensen and D. Pauly (eds.) Trophic models of aquatic ecosystems. ICLARM Conf. Proc. 26, 390

title: Engagement Indicator
summary: The engagement indicator is the extent to which all eligible countries within a given LME commit to participate to the highest level of engagement possible in agreements currently in place to address transboundary issues within the LME.
module: Governance
definition: The engagement indicator is the extent to which all eligible countries within a given LME commit to participate to the highest level of engagement possible in agreements currently in place to address transboundary issues within the LME.
unit: Percent
rationale: Success in achieving the objectives of regional agreements aimed at addressing transboundary issues depends on the level to which countries within LMEs commit to fully participate in these agreements, be they voluntary or binding. As such, assessing the level of country engagement for these agreements provide insight into possible gaps in governance efforts at the regional level.
interlink: Processes in place that influence decisions taken within transboundary rivers systems and lakes have the potential to significantly affect governance of transboundary issues in LMEs and subsequently, the open ocean. This is most noticeable for land-based sources of pollution which find their way to LMEs and eventually the open ocean. Arrangements in place to address biodiversity as well as fisheries for species that are diadromous can also be impacted by governance processes in place (or not) within other transboundary water systems.
measurements: Two variables, the nature of the agreement (in terms of whether it is a non-binding agreement facilitating collaboration or one of a binding nature) and the level of engagement of member countries in these agreements were considered important aspects of LME governance. The nature of each agreement was obtained by reviewing the text of the agreement and the highest level of engagement possible for each agreement was assessed. To provide a measure of the actual level of country engagement in each transboundary agreement relevant to a given LME, the status of each country for each agreement was researched. For binding agreements, countries that have demonstrated the highest level of engagement possible through ratification, accession, approval or acceptance, were considered to be ‘bound’ by the agreement. For non-binding agreements, countries providing evidence of their intent to fully participate in such agreements were considered ‘committed’ to the agreement. An overall engagement score for a given LME is derived from the sum of scores of engagement by countries in the LME for all binding and non-binding agreements and expressed as a percentage.
scale: Regionally for all LMEs
data_source: ECOLEX http://www.ecolex.org/start.php , National University of Singapore http://cil.nus.edu.sg/2009/cil-documents-database/ , University of Oslo, Faculty of Law, treaty database http://www.jus.uio.no/english/services/library/treaties/

title: Fishing-in-Balance Index
summary: The FiB index is defined such that its value remains the same when a downward trend in mean trophic level is compensated for by an increase in the volume of ‘catch’, as should happen given the pyramidal nature of energy flows in ecosystems and the transfer efficiency of about 10% between trophic levels alluded to above (Pauly and others 2000). The index is scaled to the first year of the time series, and usually expressed on a log-scale so that the starting value is zero.
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 1)
definition: The FiB index is defined such that its value remains the same when a downward trend in mean trophic level is compensated for by an increase in the volume of ‘catch’, as should happen given the pyramidal nature of energy flows in ecosystems and the transfer efficiency of about 10% between trophic levels alluded to above (Pauly and others 2000). The index is scaled to the first year of the time series, and usually expressed on a log-scale so that the starting value is zero.
unit: None
rationale: Evaluates if a change in the Marine Trophic Index is balanced by a corresponding change in catch levels.
measurements: Calculation details are given above. Limitations are similar to the MTI, with the added uncertainty caused by the assumption of energy transfer efficiency of 10% between trophic levels (Pauly and Christensen 1995). Supplements the MTI and should preferably be interpreted in connection with this index.
scale: Can be estimated for any given spatial scale. Analysis typically covers from 1950 to the present.
data_source: The index relies primarily on catch data, trophic levels typically from FishBase and SeaLifeBase, and an assumed trophic transfer efficiency of 10%.

title: Integration Indicator
summary: The integration indicator measures the degree to which arrangements in place to address identified transboundary issues within a given LME share similar organizations across each of seven stages of the policy cycle or the extent to which separate provision is made for integration. The seven stages of the policy cycle are analysis and advice (policy and planning), decision-making (policy and planning), implementation, review and data and information.
module: Governance
definition: The integration indicator measures the degree to which arrangements in place to address identified transboundary issues within a given LME share similar organizations across each of seven stages of the policy cycle or the extent to which separate provision is made for integration. The seven stages of the policy cycle are analysis and advice (policy and planning), decision-making (policy and planning), implementation, review and data and information.
unit: Unit interval [0,1]
rationale: There is no a priori criterion for the extent of shared responsibility across policy cycle stages that would be considered optimal. However, the assumption underpinning integration as a governance indicator was based on an expectation that without considerable attention to linkages and interaction among arrangements, it would be difficult to have the integrated approach within a system that is needed to achieve EBM. As such, the sharing of organizations across the policy cycle stages for arrangements addressing transboundary issues within a given LME is considered to be an important component of the institutional arrangements needed for governing transboundary issues of concern in LMEs. Furthermore, there may be instances in which sharing of organizational responsibility is low, but separate institutional arrangements have been made for integration and are considered.
interlink: Processes in place that influence decisions taken within transboundary rivers systems and lakes have the potential to significantly affect governance of transboundary issues in LMEs and subsequently, the open ocean. This is most noticeable for land-based sources of pollution which find their way to LMEs and eventually the open ocean. Arrangements in place to address biodiversity as well as fisheries for species that are diadromous can also be impacted by governance processes in place (or not) within other transboundary water systems.
measurements: A score for the level of integration across all of the arrangements within an LME that address the identified transboundary issues was arrived at by a two-step process. The integration score for any LME ranged between 0 and 1.0. The first step was to determine whether there was a demonstrated attempt by the countries in the region to develop and support an overarching integrating mechanism for the issues associated with fisheries, pollution and biodiversity in the LME. If so, the LME was given a score of 1 for integration. If not, the second step was to assess the degree of integration across all of the arrangements within the LME based on the extent to which the arrangements had common responsible organizations.
scale: Regionally for all LMEs
data_source: Proximate: TWAP LME and Open Ocean arrangements database. title: Marine Trophic Index
summary: Mean trophic level in fisheries catches
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 1)
definition: Mean trophic level in fisheries catches
unit: None
rationale: Once larger fish are depleted, fisheries then turn to less desirable, smaller fish. With a trophic level (TL) assigned to each of the species in the FAO landings data set, Pauly and others (1998) were able to identify a worldwide decline in the trophic level of fish landings (‘fishing down marine food webs’). The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) adopted the mean trophic level of fisheries catch, which it renamed Marine Trophic Index (MTI) as one of eight biodiversity indicators for “immediate testing” (CBD 2004, Pauly and Watson 2005).
measurements:
TLs are assigned to all catches from a given area, typically based on information in FishBase or SeaLifeBase. The weighted TL of the catch is then calculated by weighting the species/group TL with the corresponding catch level. Among the limitations are: Diagnosing fishing down from the mean trophic level of landings is problematic as landings reflect abundances only crudely; The trophic level is typically assumed constant for a given species/group, but may change over time, notably if the size of individuals in the catches change; Changes in MTI may reflect spatial expansion of fisheries, which can cause temporary increases in the index.

The MTI is closely related to the Fishing-in-Balance (FiB) index, and should preferably be interpreted in connection with this index.
scale: Can be estimated for any given spatial scale. Covers from 1950 to 2010.
data_source: Primarily based on catch data and trophic level estimates, typically from FishBase and SeaLifeBase.
agencies: University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre, Vancouver, Canada - Sea Around Us, FishBase, SeaLifeBase
references:
CBD (2004) Annex I, decision VII/30. The 2020 biodiversity target: a framework for implementation, p. 351. Decisions from the Seventh Meeting of the Conference of the Parties of the Convention on Biological Diversity, Kuala Lumpur, 9–10 and 27 February 2004. Montreal: Secretariat of the CBD.

Modelled macro and micro plastics distribution

title: Modelled macro and micro plastics distribution
summary: Relative quantities of floating micro- (<4.75mm) and macro- (>4.75mm) plastics in LMEs, based on a model of surface water circulation and the use of proxy inputs (shipping density, coastal population density, area of impermeable catchment i.e. urban areas with rapid run-off).
module: Pollution
definition: Relative quantities of floating micro- (<4.75mm) and macro- (>4.75mm) plastics in LMEs, based on a model of surface water circulation and the use of proxy inputs (shipping density, coastal population density, area of impermeable catchment i.e. urban areas with rapid run-off).
unit:
Count density: counts.km-2
Weight Density: g.km-2
rationale: Plastic pollution is globally distributed across all oceans due to its properties of buoyancy and durability, and the sorption of toxicants to plastic while traveling through the environment have led some researchers to claim that synthetic polymers in the ocean should be regarded as hazardous waste. However, there are rather few reliable observational data on the quantities of macro- and micro-plastics in most LMEs. This method provides an internally-consistent approach to indicating the relative importance of floating plastic in each LME.
interlink: The modelled distribution is a sub-set of the output at a global scale.
measurements: Surface net tows and visual survey transects combined with a calibrated oceanographic model of floating debris.
scale: Global grid at 0.2 nautical degree resolution.

title: Nutrient loading and eutrophication potential
summary: LME-scale inputs of nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus and silica, in different forms) from rivers, and corresponding nutrient-ratio sub-indicator (the Indicator of Coastal Eutrophication Potential, ICEP). The N load sub-indicator is a measure of the amount of nitrogen carried by rivers as they enter the land-sea boundary of the LME.  Nitrogen is the nutrient generally most limiting to biomass production in coastal waters and the form of N most rapidly used is dissolved inorganic N (DIN – ammonia plus nitrate).  DIN is also the form of N which increases the most in rivers, and therefore delivered to LMEs, with increase in human activity.  Therefore the N load indicator is based on the river DIN load. DIN and ICEP values are categorized based on the literature and expert knowledge to produce sub-indicator values, and an approach is devised that results in a single merged indicator.  Results are provided for the year 2000 and future scenarios for 2030 and 2050.
module: Pollution
definition: LME-scale inputs of nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus and silica, in different forms) from rivers, and corresponding nutrient-ratio sub-indicator (the Indicator of Coastal Eutrophication Potential, ICEP). The N load sub-indicator is a measure of the amount of nitrogen carried by rivers as they enter the land-sea boundary of the LME. Nitrogen is the nutrient generally most limiting to biomass production in coastal waters and the form of N most rapidly used is dissolved inorganic N (DIN – ammonia plus nitrate). DIN is also the form of N which increases the most in rivers, and therefore delivered to LMEs, with increase in human activity. Therefore the N load indicator is based on the river DIN load. DIN and ICEP values are categorized based on the literature and expert knowledge to produce sub-indicator values, and an approach is devised that results in a single merged indicator. Results are provided for the year 2000 and future scenarios for 2030 and 2050.
unit:
Total river drainage area (stnbasin_area): km2
Total river drainage discharge (qact): km3.year-1
Nutrient Loads: Tg (of N, P or Si) year-1
ICEP: kg.C.km-2.day-1
Indicator Categories: unitless (categories 1-5, where 5 is highest impact)
rationale: Land use and human activities in watersheds are affecting nutrients transported by rivers into LMEs. Excess nutrients (nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), silica (Si)) entering coastal waters of LMEs can result in high biomass algal blooms, leading to hypoxic or anoxic conditions, increased turbidity, and changes in community composition, among other effects. In addition to the amount of nutrients, changes in the ratio of nutrients entering LMEs can result in dominance by algal species (e.g., dinoflagellates) that have deleterious effects (toxic, clog gills of shellfish, etc.) on ecosystems and humans. An overall indicator of coastal eutrophication, based on 2 sub-indicators, was developed. The sub-indicators were based on dissolved inorganic N loading rates and on nutrient ratios.
interlink: This study directly builds on the river basin component of the GEF TWAP. The TWAP River Basins component also uses the Global NEWS model and addresses contemporary conditions, and 2030 and 2050 assessments using the same "current trends" scenario to develop a river nutrient pollution indicator. A related project was conducted for the Bay of Bengal LME (BOB LME) which went substantially beyond the TWAP in both the level of spatial detail of nutrient input to the LME (individual river basin information) and in providing N and P source information in the river basins draining into the BOB LME (e.g., sewage, agriculture from crops and from livestock, atmospheric deposition directly to watershed).
measurements: River nutrient loadings (exports) are based on annual-scale output at river mouths from the Global NEWS 2 model encompassing different nutrient elements (N, P, Si) and forms (dissolved inorganic, dissolved organic, and particulate). This model is driven by spatially distributed, natural and anthropogenic factors within watersheds, including climate, land use, hydrology, human point sources of nutrients (sewage), and nutrient retention and withdrawal in the river network. The Indicator of Coastal Eutrophication Potential is calculated from Global NEWS 2 river nutrient loadings. All river-basin-scale results are aggregated to the LME scale based on the geographical location of river mouths relative to LME boundaries. Results are not provided for 3 high-latitude LME's, as no corresponding river exports were modelled for these highly glaciated regions. The Global NEWS 2 model run used here is referred to as the Realistic Hydrology Model Run for reference year 2000 (RH2000), and corresponds to near-contemporary conditions using the year 2000 as a reference for all basin model inputs and forcings (Mayorga et al, 2010). RH2000 is based on observed climate forcings and river discharge corrections from river gage observations, and was developed to represent contemporary conditions more realistically than the year-2000 reference model run used in the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment Scenarios (MEA) assessment presented in Seitzinger et al. (2010) and related publications. MEA scenarios represent internally consistent, plausible global futures that focus on implications for ecosystem services; forcing data include not only climate change, hydrology, water use, population, and GDP, but also nutrient management options for agriculture (crop and livestock) and sewage treatment. Results for future projections (2030 and 2050) are scaled to the RH2000 baseline and are based on model inputs and forcings from the MEA Global Orchestration (GO) scenario (Seitzinger et al. 2010). GO describes a globalized world with a focus on economic development with rapid economic and urbanization growth, and a reactive environmental management approach.
scale: LME
data_source: Global NEWS 2 model output for river nutrient exports (loadings) to the coast (Beusen et al, 2009; Mayorga et al, 2010; Seitzinger et al, 2010), and the application of the ICEP indicator of coastal eutrophication potential using these nutrient loadings (defined in Garnier et al, 2010; applied for the TWAP LME project using the Global NEWS 2 data).

Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) in plastic resin pellets

title: Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs) in plastic resin pellets
summary: Concentration of POPs in beached plastic resin pellets.
module: Pollution
definition: Concentration of POPs in beached plastic resin pellets.
unit: ng.g-1
rationale: Plastic resin pellets are ubiquitous in coastal waters, derived primarily from accidental releases of pellets during transport or trans-shipment, and from their use in a number of industrial and consumer applications. The pellets absorb hydrophobic compounds such as POPs present in the surrounding seawater, with a concentration factor of up to 1,000,000 (Smeddes and others, 2009)
interlink: Concentrations of POPs in LMEs indicate variations in land-use and industrial development in the adjoining catchments, and are relevant to rivers. In addition there is evidence for the export of pellets to the open ocean (Lohman and others, 2010).
measurements: Collection of beached resin pellets by volunteers and agencies and analysis at suitable analytical laboratory (e.g., Tokyo university of Agriculture & Technology). The pellet analysis provides a semi-quantitative indicator of pollution state in seawater, as there is limited control of the "age" of the particle, and hence the available equilibration time.
scale: LME or subregion
data_source: The International Pellet Watch programme has established a global network of volunteers who collect pellets from beaches and send them to a single laboratory for analysis (Ogata and others 2009). The results are sent to the collectors and made available on the programme website www.pelletwatch.org
agencies: International Pellet Watch www.pelletwatch.org; Laboratory of Organic Geochemistry, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology

title: Predicted catch potential (2030)
summary: The maximum exploitable catch over species combined, assuming that the geographic range and selectivity of fisheries remain unchanged from the current (the 2000s) level.
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 2)
definition: The maximum exploitable catch over species combined, assuming that the geographic range and selectivity of fisheries remain unchanged from the current (the 2000s) level.
unit: tons.year-1
rationale: Marine fisheries productivity is likely to be affected by the alteration of ocean conditions including water temperature, ocean currents and coastal upwelling, as a result of climate change (e.g., Bakun 1990, IPCC 2007, Diaz and Rosenberg 2008).
interlink: Here considered for marine and estuarine systems jointly.
measurements: Based on analysis of 1066 species of marine fish and invertebrates, representing the major commercially exploited species, as reported in the FAO fisheries statistics (see http://www.fao.org). Future distributions of these species are projected using a dynamic bioclimate envelope model under the SRES A1B scenario (see Cheung and others 2008b, 2009) while primary production is projected by empirical models (Behrenfeld and Falkowski 1997, Carr 2002, Marra and others 2003, Sarmiento and others 2004). The annual maximum catch potential for ½˚ by ½˚ spatial cells is calculated based on the model of Cheung and others (2008). The empirical model estimates a species’ maximum catch potential (MSY) based on the total primary production within its exploitable range, the area of its geographic range, its trophic level, and includes terms correcting the biases from the observed catch potential. Development of alternative methods should be encouraged.
scale: ½°×½° spatial cells, global coverage, summarized to spatial areas. Compares catch potential for 2055 relative to 2005.
data_source: Output from the global dataset is available from the Sea Around Us project. There are a number of recognized limitations (see Cheung and others 2008).
agencies: UBC Sea Around Us project, University of East Anglia, Princeton University

title: Primary productivity
summary: Primary productivity is the rate of organic matter production by plants. The bulk of marine Primary Productivity is carried out by phytoplankton, which can be seen from space due to their photosynthetic pigments (mainly chlorophyll).
module: Productivity
category: Ecosystem state
definition: Primary productivity is the rate of organic matter production by plants. The bulk of marine Primary Productivity is carried out by phytoplankton, which can be seen from space due to their photosynthetic pigments (mainly chlorophyll).
unit:
g.C.m-2.d-1
gram of Carbon per square meter per day
rationale: Primary production forms the basis of the marine food web, and can be related to the carrying capacity of an ecosystem for supporting fish resources.
interlink: Rivers are a central link in nutrient transfer from watersheds to coastal systems, and resulting eutrophication and water quality degradation in LMEs.
measurements: Primary productivity estimates originate from ocean color sensors and satellites including the Ocean Color and Thermal Sensor (OCTS), Sea-viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor (SeaWiFS), and Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS-Aqua and MODISTerra). A large archive of in situ near surface chlorophyll data, and satellite SST measurements made by Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) flown on NOAA satellites is used to quantify spatial and seasonal variability of near-surface chlorophyll and SST. Plankton can also be measured over decadal time scales by continuous plankton recorder systems as deployed by the Sir Alistair Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS) from commercial vessels of opportunity.
scale: Globally for all LMEs, Annual trends 1996-2013
data_source: NOAA’s Northeast Fisheries Science Center, Narragansett Laboratory.

title: Stock-Catch-Status plots
summary: A newly proposed type of paired ‘Stock-Catch-Status Plots’ (% of stocks of a given status and % of catches extracted from stocks of a given status), wherein the status of stocks, i.e., species with a time series of landings in an LME, is assessed, based on Froese and Kesner-Reyes (2002), using the following criteria (all referring to the maximum catch in the series): Developing (catches < 50 %); Fully exploited (catches >= 50%); Overexploited (catches between 50% and 10%); Collapsed (catches < 10%)
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Ecosystem state (Level 1)
definition: A newly proposed type of paired ‘Stock-Catch-Status Plots’ (% of stocks of a given status and % of catches extracted from stocks of a given status), wherein the status of stocks, i.e., species with a time series of landings in an LME, is assessed, based on Froese and Kesner-Reyes (2002), using the following criteria (all referring to the maximum catch in the series): Developing (catches < 50 %); Fully exploited (catches >= 50%); Overexploited (catches between 50% and 10%); Collapsed (catches < 10%)
unit: Status by stock (catch category) or as proportion of catch
rationale: Stock status plots document, for a series of years, the fraction of the reported landings that is derived from stocks in various phases of development or exploitation status.
measurements:
These graphs have their origin in the work of Granger and Garcia (1996), who fitted time series of landings of the most important species in the FAO database with high-order polynomials, and evaluated from their slopes whether the fisheries were in their ‘developing’, ‘fully utilized’ or ‘senescent’ phases. Froese and Kesner-Reyes (2002) simplified these graphs by defining for any time series, five phases relative to the maximum reported landing in that time series, representing a ‘stock’. Here, a variant of what may be called ‘stock number by status plots’ is used: a ‘catch by status plot’, defined such that it documents, for a series of years, the fraction of the reported landings biomass that is derived from stocks in various phases of development (as opposed to the number of such stocks) (Pauly and others 2008). Stock status plots can be expressed relative to number of stocks or weighted by the catches by stocks. Limitations include:

  • • The undeveloped and the developing categories will by definition have disappeared by the end of the time series since the scale is based on the year with maximum catch (which has to occur somewhere on the time line),
  • • Catches may not say much about the stock status if, e.g., catch reductions are due to management interventions.
scale: Analysis can be done at the national, LME, and Regional Seas level, i.e. at any level where it is deemed appropriate to relate stock status to the signals from landings.
data_source: The status plots rely on analysis of catches only, which are available from the Sea Around Us project. Time coverage is from 1950 to the present, in annual steps. It is assumed that the catches are reflective of the underlying population (stock) status.
agencies: FAO, University of Kiel, University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre, Vancouver, Canada - Sea Around Us
references:
Froese, R. and K. Kesner-Reyes (2002). Impact of Fishing on the Abundance of Marine Species. Rainer. ICES CM 2002/L:12, 15 p.
Grainger, R.J.R. and S. Garcia (1996). Chronicles of marine fisheries landings (1950-1994): trend analysis and fisheries potential. FAO Fish. Tech. Pap. 359, 51 p.
Pauly, D., J. Alder, S. Booth, W.W.L. Cheung, V. Christensen, C. Close, U.R. Sumaila, W. Swartz, A. Tavakolie, R. Watson, L. Wood and D. Zeller. 2008. Fisheries in Large Marine Ecosystems: Descriptions and Diagnoses. p. 23-40. In: K. Sherman and G. Hempel (eds.) The UNEP Large Marine Ecosystem Report: a Perspective on Changing Conditions in LMEs of the World’s Regional Seas. UNEP Regional Seas Reports and Studies No. 182

title: Value of fisheries landings
summary: Value of fisheries landings in year 2000 inflation-adjusted prices.
module: Fish and Fisheries
category: Socio-economic driver (Level 1)
definition: Value of fisheries landings in year 2000 inflation-adjusted prices.
unit: USD.year-1
rationale: Fishing effort is one of the major stress factors for marine ecosystems, and effort is in turn directly influenced by the value of the landings. It is a function (but not linear) of the fisheries landings.
interlink: NA
measurements: Relies on a database of ex-vessel fish price, which is based on observed prices in different countries at different times for different species; and inferred prices, based on observed prices and an averaging algorithm which took taxonomic affinity, adjacency of countries and time into account (Sumaila and others 2007). The year-, species- and time-specific prices in the database where then adjusted for inflation to year 2000 real prices in US$, using consumer price index data from the World Bank, and multiplied by the spatially allocated landings for the corresponding years and species (groups). This yielded time series of the value of fisheries landings in year 2000 inflation adjusted prices, which can be compared in time and space. As observed prices were available for the most important commercial species, the inferred prices have little influence on the total value of landings.
scale: LME (value for landings by groups/species by year), 1950 – 2010
data_source: Based on the global price database of Sumaila and others (2007), made available through the Sea Around Us website (www.seaaroundus.org)
agencies: University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre, Vancouver, Canada - Sea Around Us
references: Sumaila, R. A.D. Marsden, R. Watson and D. Pauly (2007). A global ex-vessel price database: construction and applications. Journal of Bioeconomics 9:39-51
